text: [Applause]
[Music]
[Applause]
hello everyone thanks for having me
today so I'm gonna tell you a little bit
about a job that I bet many of you are
thinking about and that's the kind of
job that's involved with working with
animals so how many of you out there
might think especially for the students
out there that you might be interested
in a job working with animals some day
show of hands some people out there so
as bill mentioned I'm actually in my
daily life a professor so I work at sort
of stodgy buildings like this out at
Yale but I sort of live a bit of a dual
life it's kind of a monkey Wrangler or
as I'll tell you a little bit about
today a monkey illusionists
so how did I get into this well the
reason I got into this is that I'm not
actually interested in monkeys I'm
interested in actually what I think is
the most fundamental problem out there
and that's the problem of how we think
what makes us the way we are how do we
as humans do all the cool things that we
do like speak and use tools and
understand numbers understand each other
all these crazy things that humans do we
understand very little about how we come
to do them when I was in high school I
was really interested in history so I
wanted to take a bit of a historic
approach to this problem which brought
me to the field of evolution and trying
to think how does the human mind change
over evolutionary time so what I really
wanted to do as a scientist was to go
find these guys and study how they made
sense of their world but there's a
problem with this approach which is
unfortunately all of our good ancestors
to do this are actually dead so you're a
bit out of a job unless you could come
up with a better way to study these
kinds of questions and the way that I do
it is through the use of our closest
living relatives the non-human primates
so here's a quick look at your very very
old family tree back about 50 million
years ago the tops of the tree are the
guys that are alive today and for those
of you who are recognizing there's one
of them that's the yale graduate over
there this is to remind us a little bit
that evolution is in the ladder with
humans at the top but a branching tree
are all equal at the top but I actually
study the first three guys on this tree
the most distantly related primates the
first guys I work with are these guys
here are the lemurs which I study in a
forest enclosure that's way out
the middle of Florida known as the lemur
Conservation Foundation and this
Conservation Foundation is home to five
different lemur species these
ring-tailed lemurs bamboo lemurs
mongoose lemurs brown lemurs and also
these red ruffed lemurs and what we can
do is actually go out into the forest
with the lemurs and actually try to
study how they think right out there in
the forest and sometimes we get you know
perhaps a little bit too up close and
personal with the lemurs but you know we
don't mind too too much the second group
of monkeys that I study are these guys
here these are the most distantly
related group of monkeys the brown
capuchin monkeys we actually have the
luxury of study and group of capuchin
monkeys that we have out at yale where
we can actually get even more up close
and personal with them here's a group of
family capuchins some of whom are living
at your knees right now so that's the
second group that I study and then from
there we actually get to the group that
bill is talking about earlier these are
the most closely related group of
monkeys who I work most with and they
actually live wonderfully enough for my
job on a beautiful island right off the
coast of Puerto Rico which is known as
Cayo Santiago and it's an island home of
800 rhesus macaque so there are no
humans on the island just monkeys so we
can go out with the monkeys in their
naturalistic environment and try to
figure out how what they know and how
their mind works but this raises this
question of if you're really interested
in how the monkey mind works how do you
ask a monkey what he knows about the
world well the answer that I have might
actually surprise you a little bit
because one of the central techniques we
use to get at what monkeys know is
actually through the use of magic and
how does that work well when I say magic
I really do mean magic I mean straight
up David Copperfield stuff but we said
we can actually use the same kind of
magic with monkeys to try to see if we
show monkeys magical events do they get
surprised too and that's just what we do
down at these field sites where we work
it usually involves three important
pieces here the first piece of course is
you have to find a monkey you probably
have to have one of my students here
Kelly being a magician showing them some
kind of magical event and the important
thing from the research perspective is
we also have a camera person who's
actually videotaping the monkey and he's
gonna be measuring whether or not the
monkey actually gets surprised so we can
use this technique to see all kinds of
things that the monkeys know about there
I'll show you just one quick one so
here's an experiment that we did to try
to look at whether or not these lemurs
understand math do they know that one
plus one equals two well to look at this
what we did was just to present the
lemurs a magical event in which
sometimes one plus one doesn't equal two
so here's my student neha she's showing
the lemurs this event and she's just
gonna add one lemon plus one lemon in
this box and then she's gonna show him
either real outcomes in which one plus
one equals two so when she opens the box
up there's two lemons no magic there or
are these sort of interesting magical
events after which she adds one plus one
and now it only equals one and when
students of mine and colleagues of mine
did this type of work with lemurs and
monkeys what we find is that the monkeys
show surprise based on how long they
look at stuff so when monkeys see that
top event when one plus one eggplant
actually just equals two they think this
is sort of boring they only looked for
about one second but whenever you show
them unexpected or magical events in
which one plus one doesn't equal two
they increase their looking and seem to
show something like surprise that we can
measure not just to see their surprise
but to show what they really understand
about the world so we've been able to
use this to look at all kinds of
different things such as what the
monkeys understand about tools showing
them magical tools showing the magical
machines that work in ways that don't
causally work sometimes we get even
extra interest you can see one of the
fun things about this job is you have to
design weird machines with that man that
monkeys don't really understand very
much but just to end off it's not just
that we're designing these monkey magic
tricks it's not just that we use this
technique because one of the problems of
being a monkey researcher is that you
have to stay on your toes all of the
time so here's a scene of me doing the
same kind of experiment we take if you
do I'm over here being the magician and
one thing we notice is that the monkeys
are very crafty creatures and whenever
we happen to look away from what was
going on in our box
like this would happen or hey hey hey
thanks yep
and this is what happens when a monkey
runs away with all of your eggplants so
my camera person's a prat what's
happened the eggplants are gone we can't
keep going
but what we realized was that the
monkeys were doing something actually
quite smart because they only tried to
steal the food that we had when we were
looking away and we said hey thinking on
our toes maybe we can use this as a
technique to see if the monkeys know how
to deceive us so we got a bunch of guys
who look like they could be deceived
these are a bunch of freshmen from yeah
my students and we put them in
competition with the monkeys over food
so we have each of the two guys these
are my students they're standing in
front of this little platform it has a
piece of food and the question is are
the monkey smart enough to steal from
the guy who can't see them and what we
find this is just a quick video of this
you can see the guy in the middle right
there is the monkey there's my two
students they're gonna be getting their
grape and getting into position you can
see another cool thing about the job is
you also kind of have to have good dance
moves here are my guys taking their
grape stepping to the side putting it on
the ground and what you're gonna see is
the guy on the left is gonna turn around
you see he turns his head and you can
watch quickly what the monkey does
D'Andre savvy monkey you play though but
it turns out our monkeys are actually
pretty savvy what they pay attention to
is just the cues that would be smart to
decide who to steal from so they steal
only from guys who are looking away
suggesting that they also understand the
eyes mean something about seeing and
they know what it means for somebody to
know something and therefore that you
can't deceive them so just to let you
know that working with monkeys isn't
actually a day on the beach you have to
worry about all these kinds of things
staying on your toes trying not to get
stolen from and you might have the
unfortunate thing of actually getting
your Apple stolen there's a monkey
running away from my course student Eric
having monkeys really worried about
their own data and sort of wanting to
see into it and also occasionally having
a lemur using you as a lawn chair but
all in all it's actually not such a bad
gig I think thanks
